summary: Defense attorney Bobbi Sternheim's letter to Judge Alison Nathan requesting a 90-day continuance of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial from July 12, 2021, due to the government's filing of a superseding indictment that added new charges and expanded the alleged conspiracy period from 1994-2004. The letter argues the defense needs time to investigate new witnesses and review millions of pages of discovery now relevant to the expanded charges.

keyFacts: The government filed a superseding indictment that expanded the alleged conspiracy period from a 4-year period in the 1990s to an 11-year period from 1994 to 2004, adding two new charges.
The defense received over 20,000 pages of materials related to 226 non-testifying witnesses on April 13, 2021, which they claim contains exculpatory information requiring investigation.

Discovery includes over 2.4 million pages from Jeffrey Epstein's seized electronic devices, which were previously considered largely irrelevant but now must be re-reviewed due to the expanded time frame.
The defense argues COVID-19 restrictions have severely hampered their ability to conduct a meaningful investigation for the new charges.
The defense requests a minimum 90-day continuance, stating that without it, the trial likely could not occur before mid-January 2022 due to counsel's other commitments.
